Cell.Data: Application Schema <provide name of source schema>

The quantity of a mineral (or a group of minerals for industrial rocks) in accumulations (deposits) meeting specified physical characteristics such as quality, size and depth. Usually includes Resources, as unlike the latter, it does not have to have prospects for "eventual economic extraction". It often includes the total amount of a commodity originally introduced to a particular location during the deposit forming processes - and thus can include resources, reserves, past production and mining and metallurgical losses.
Means of calculating the measurement. EXAMPLE: JORC, PERC, Unspecified, UNESCO/World Bank and the Canadian CIM.
Date of calculated or estimated value. This may be a single date or a range.
Size of the body used in the calculation.
The method proposed to extract the commodity.
The reference for the OreMeasure values.

A measure of the amount of each commodity, based on a reserve, resource or endowment calculation. This measure is obtained by multiplying the ore tonnage by the average grade of the commodity within the ore (generally expressed in tons of metal).
A flag indicating if the estimate includes the reserves value.
A flag indicating if the estimate includes the resources value.
A measure of the amount of the commodity based on a Reserve, Resource or Endowment calculation. Where OreMeasure is Resource or Reserve CommodityMeasure is mandatory
The cut off grade used for calculating the commodity measure. The lowest concentration of a mineralized material that qualifies as ore in a given deposit (adapted from Neuendorf, 2005).
The commodity to which the CommodityMeasure refers.

A spatial representation of a MiningFeature. A MiningFeatureOccurrence provides a link between a notional feature (description package) and one spatial representation of it, or part of it. The MiningFeatureOccurrence carries a geometry and the association with a Mining Feature provides specification of all the other descriptors.
Indicates the MiningFeature that the MiningFeatureOccurrence specifies.

Indicates the MiningFeature that the occurrence specifies Points to any number of MiningFeatureOccurrences which are occurrences of the Miningfeature. MiningFeatureOccurrences may all be from a single map or from several maps, or reflect different levels of detail, eg point, area, 3D volume.
The process of extracting metallic, non-metallic mineral, or industrial rock deposits from the Earth. The term may also include preliminary treatment eg. cleaning or sizing.
External object identifier of the spatial object.
Point to the single MiningFeature which describes the Mining feature Occurrence
The type of processing carried out during the mining activity.
Waste products from a mining activity, through a processing phase.
To which deposit a mining activity is associated.
The mine where the mining activity takes, or took, place.
The mine that the MiningActivity occurred in
The deposit to which the mining activity is associated.
Product(s) elaborated from mining activity, through a processing phase. Usually in the form of concentrates containing one or several commodities at various grades for metallic ores.

An ore is rarely extracted or mined alone. It is most of the time accompanied by a variable quantity of gangue, very slightly mineralized or completely barren, composed of non-metallic minerals (sometimes of interest) and/or altered host-rock(s).

Period, or extent in time, of the mining activity. The beginning of the activity links the TM_Period to the TM_Instant at which it starts. The ending links the TM_Period to the TM_Instant at which it ends. For a variety of reasons, the position of the TM_Instant designated by 'begin' or 'end' may be inderterminate.

The type of mining activity. EXAMPLE: Open Pit, Underground Mine, multiple, unspecified) or processing activity (eg Ore Processing) or production. Using activity to distinguish between the extraction, processing and production activities allows distinguishing between ore mined/grade/recovery, ore treated/grade/recovery and produced payable/plant recovery.
The amount of ore processed by the activity.

An excavation carried out for the extraction of mineral deposits. ‘True’ mines are underground workings and open-pit workings (also called open-sky mines) generally for the extraction of metallic commodities. The Mine feature also includes open workings generally for the extraction of industrial minerals, commonly referred to as quarries.
External object identifier of the spatial object.
Point to the single MiningFeature which describes the Mining feature Occurrence
Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.
Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.
The MiningActivity associated with the Mine.
The MiningActivity associated with the Mine
Date on which the mine commenced operation.
Data type indicating the Mine Name and whether it is the preferred name.
The source reference for the mine. Allows citing mine plans etc.
Operational status value of the mine. EXAMPLE: Care & Maintenance; Pending Approval; Operating continually.

A related mine. A mine currently exploited may result from the resumption and the extension of a – or several – former or older (abandoned) mine(s). Mines need not aggregate to form other mines, they may just be associated in some way or another (eg the Kalgoorlie SuperPit is associated with its preceding mines).
Date on which the mine ceased operation.
A data type indicating the Mine Name and whether it is the preferred name.
A boolean operator indicating if the value in mineName is the preferred name of the mine.

The economically mineable part of a Measured and/or Indicated Mineral Resource. It includes diluting materials and allowances for losses, which may occur when the material is mined. ‘Marketable Coal Reserves’ maybe reported in conjunction with, but not instead of, reports of Ore (Coal) Reserves. ‘Saleable product’ (e.g. for industrial minerals) can be reported in conjunction with ore reserve. Synonyms: Ore Reserve; Coal Reserve (s); Diamond (or gemstone) Ore Reserve; Mineral Reserves (not preferred, should be stated that used to mean the same as JORC’s Ore Reserve); Mineable production estimates
Means of calculating the measurement. EXAMPLE: JORC, PERC, Unspecified, UNESCO/World Bank and the Canadian CIM.
Date of calculated or estimated value. This may be a single date or a range.
Size of the body used in the calculation.
The method proposed to extract the commodity.
The reference for the OreMeasure values.

A measure of the amount of each commodity, based on a reserve, resource or endowment calculation. This measure is obtained by multiplying the ore tonnage by the average grade of the commodity within the ore (generally expressed in tons of metal).
The level of confidence of the estimate (proved, probable).
<font color="#400040">A mineral accumulation in the lithosphere. </font>
External object identifier of the spatial object.
The name of the geologic feature. EXAMPLE: a lithostratigraphic unit, mineral occurrence, or major fault. Not all GeologicFeatures will have names, for example minor faults.
An association that relates one or more geologic events to a geologic feature to describe their age or geologic history.
A thematic classification of the geologic feature. A GeologicFeature may be classified according to one or more thematic schema, for example ground stability or mineral resource potential.
Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was inserted or changed in the spatial data set.
Date and time at which this version of the spatial object was superseded or retired in the spatial data set.

Recaps the work which has been done from regional reconnaissance, surface detailed prospecting, subsurface prospecting, assessment of the resource, to evaluation of the ore deposit. Depending on the work done on occurrences and prospects, allows an estimate of the 'still to be discovered' potential of an area. A detailed assessment with no result would lead to a pessimistic opinion.
Provides a description for how the EarthResource formed
A supergene process which would allow a metal enrichment produced by the chemical remobilisation of metals in an oxidised or transitional environment.

Indicates if this resource is the subject of exploitation, and if so of which type. Depending on several factors (type of mineralization, size, grade, shape, depth, etc.) one or several (combined) methods may be used, including off site methods, surface mining (among which methods related to the exploitation of alluvial/elluvial deposits), underground mining. Knowledge about these methods is important as it may be strongly related to the quantity and type of wastes and environmental impacts generated by the extraction.

One or more periods of mining activity of the earth resource. Indicates if this resource is the subject of exploitation, and if so of which type. Depending on several factors (type of mineralization, size, grade, shape, depth, etc.) one or several (combined) methods may be used, including off site methods, surface mining (among which methods related to the exploitation of alluvial/elluvial deposits), underground mining. Knowledge about these methods is important as it may be strongly related to the quantity and type of wastes and environmental impacts generated by the extraction.

Chronological list of surveys undertaken to better define the potential of a mineral occurrence. Recaps the work which has been done from regional reconnaissance, surface detailed prospecting, subsurface prospecting, assessment of the resource, to evaluation of the ore deposit. Depending on the work done on occurrences and prospects, allows an estimate of the 'still to be discovered' potential of an area. A detailed assessment with no result would lead to a pessimistic opinion.

Exhaustive list of the commodities present in the resource, ranked by importance order. Determining the rank of a commodity is not as simple as it may look: not only the tonnage (expressed in tons of metal) has to be taken into account, but also the scarcity and thus the price of the commodity. A deposit containing 500,000 t Cu and only 50 t Au will be classified as an Au-(Cu) deposit.

The commodities present in the resource ranked by importance order. Determining the rank of a commodity is not as simple as it may look: not only the tonnage (expressed in tons of metal) has to be taken into account, but also the scarcity and thus the price of the commodity. A deposit containing 500,000 t Cu and only 50 t Au will be classified as an Au-(Cu) deposit.
The source or reference for the Earth Resource.
The size/volume of the earth resource.
An indicator of whether an EarthResource appears on the surface or has been detected under cover rocks.
The orebody's typical physical and structural relationship to wallrocks and associated rocks. EXAMPLE: stratiform, stratabound, cross-cutting, vein, intrusive contact etc.
The linear orientation of the Earth Resource. EXAMPLE: Plunge etc.
The planar orientation of the Earth Resource. EXAMPLE: Dip/Dip Direction etc.
The typical geometrical shape of the Earth Resource. EXAMPLE: lenticular, pipelike, irregular etc.
Classification of the EarthResource. Systematically arranged information describing the essential attributes of a class of mineral deposits. May be empirical (descriptive) or theoretical (genetic).
The estimated or calculated amount of ore with the identification of the commodities contained and their grade.
The type of mineral occurrence. EXAMPLE: prospect, occurrence, mineral deposit, ore deposit.
The end-use potential of the mineral. EXAMPLE: for energy, fertilizer, building raw material.
The material of economic interest in the EarthResource
The deposit/resource from which the commodity comes.
The deposit/resource from which the commodity comes.
The earth resource commodity. EXAMPLE: Cu, Au, Dimension Stone etc.

The importance of the deposit for the commodity. Several commodities may be of interest inside a deposit. A deposit may be a very large deposit for one commodity (this commodity is the main one) and only a medium-sized deposit for some other commodities. Such a ranking is based on a statistical study of a large set of deposits throughout the world to ensure that it is valid. It is made using histograms allowing for each commodity to define class boundaries and what is a super large, a large, a medium-sized etc deposit for this commodity. This classification is based on the potential or endowment: reserves + resources.

The rank of the commodity. Commodity rank is based on endowment, i.e. (cumulated) past production + reserves (not including past production) + resources, or if the deposit has never been exploited, reserves + resources. A statistical comparison with a large set of deposits throughout the world enables the determination of the deposit as class A (very large), B (large), or C (medium-sized) for a particular commodity, and also which commodity is the main one, the 2nd one, etc. The rank of a commodity is thus not based on political or economic considerations.

An accumulation of material of intrinsic economic interest in or on the Earth’s crust in such form, quality and quantity that there are reasonable prospects for economic extraction. Synonyms: Mineral Resource; Coal Resource (s); Diamond (Gemstone) Resource; Potentially Mineable Mineralisation.
Means of calculating the measurement. EXAMPLE: JORC, PERC, Unspecified, UNESCO/World Bank and the Canadian CIM.
Date of calculated or estimated value. This may be a single date or a range.
Size of the body used in the calculation.
The method proposed to extract the commodity.
The reference for the OreMeasure values.

A measure of the amount of each commodity, based on a reserve, resource or endowment calculation. This measure is obtained by multiplying the ore tonnage by the average grade of the commodity within the ore (generally expressed in tons of metal).
Indication of whether the resource is measured, indicated, or inferred.
A flag indicating whether the estimate of resources includes reserve values.

Period, or extent in time, of the exploration activity. The beginning of the activity links the TM_Period to the TM_Instant at which it starts. The ending links the TM_Period to the TM_Instant at which it ends. For a variety of reasons, the position of the TM_Instant designated by 'begin' or 'end' may be inderterminate.
The type of exploration activity. EXAMPLE: geological mapping, drilling, geophysical surveys, geochemical mapping, etc.
The result of the exploration activity.
Systematically arranged information describing the essential attributes of a class of mineral deposits. It may be empirical (descriptive) or theoretical (genetic).

A grouping of mineral deposits defined by generic characteristics EXAMPLE: host rock, host structure, commodity, association with similar mineral processes e.g. porphyry. Regional, national and more universal lists e.g. Cox and Singer 1986.

Style of mineral occurrence or deposit. Generally a local or regional term. Should be referenced for definitions and descriptions. Single deposit terms may form member of a Mineral Deposit Group in local and regional schemas.
The size and volume of the earth resource.
The area of the Earth Resource.
The depth of the Earth Resource.
The length of the Earth Resource.
The width of the Earth Resource.
